means.word_mean: 可能性,实用性;风险;机遇

derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English: from Old French possibilite, from late Latin possibilitas, from possibilis 'able to be done' (see possible)

entry.def: If you say there is a possibility that something is the case or that something will happen, you mean that it might be the case or it might happen.

example.ex: We were not in the least worried about the possibility that sweets could rot the teeth...
example.tran: 我们以前完全不担心吃糖果有可能会蛀牙。

example.ex: Tax on food has become a very real possibility.

entry.def: A possibility is one of several different things that could be done.

example.ex: The government now owns a lot of our land — one possibility would be  to compensate us with other property...
example.tran: 政府现在占了我们的大量土地，一种可能是用其他地产来对我们作出补偿。

example.ex: There were several possibilities open to each manufacturer.
example.tran: 每个制造商都可以有几种不同的选择。

entry.def: You can say 'It is not beyond the realms of possibility' or 'It is not beyond the bounds of possibility'  when you are stating something that you believe is possibly true, but which other people might consider unlikely or impossible.

example.ex: It's not beyond the realms of possibility that the security services do bug important public figures.
example.tran: 安全部门完全有可能窃听重要公众人物的谈话。

means.word_mean: 2. capability of existing or happening or being true;

sentences.sentence: "there is a possibility that his sense of smell has been impaired"

means.word_mean: 3. a tentative theory about the natural world; a concept that is not yet verified but that if true would explain certain facts or phenomena;

sentences.sentence: "a scientific hypothesis that survives experimental testing becomes a scientific theory"
"he proposed a fresh theory of alkalis that later was accepted in chemical practices"

stems_affixes.value_cn: 可能的, 可能存在或发生的
stems_affixes.word_buile: poss可以,能够，有能力+ible表形容词→adj.可能的, 可能存在或发生的
possible[adj.可能的, 可能存在或发生的]+ly表副词→possibly可能地

stems_affixes.value_cn: 可能性, 可能发生的事物
stems_affixes.word_buile: poss可以,能够，有能力+ibility具备……性质的→可能性

Sentence.sentence: She was astonished by the professional possibilities afforded to young American woman.
In 1966, soon after the Beatles had finished work on "Rubber Soul", Paul McCartney looked into the possibility of going to America to record their next album.

Researchers studying teenagers in Israel concluded that, in that hazardous environment, mobile phones were regarded as "security objects" in parent-teen relationships―important because they provided the possibility ofcontact and communication at all times
